journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Reinforced Plastics and Composites

title-group.article-title: Electrical, optical, and rheological properties of ozone-treated multiwalled carbon nanotubes–polystyrene nanocomposites

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Physics, College of Science, King Faisal University, Al Ahsa, Kingdom of Saudi Arabia
2Physics Department, Faculty of Science, Cairo University, Giza, Egypt

author-notes.corresp: Ayman S Ayesh, Department of Physics, College of Science, King Faisal University, P.O. Box 400, 31982, Al-Ahsa, Kingdom of Saudi Arabia. Email: assalem@kfu.edu.sa

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2013 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: The functionalization of multiwalled carbon nanotubes was performed through the treatment of multiwalled carbon nanotubes with ozone using UV-ozone irradiation to improve their dispersion in polystyrene matrix. Multiwalled carbon nanotubes–polystyrene nanocomposites were prepared at different multiwalled carbon nanotubes weight ratios to investigate the effect of multiwalled carbon nanotubes loadings on the electrical, optical, and rheological properties of polystyrene matrix. The obtained results revealed that incorporation of functionalized multiwalled carbon nanotubes into polystyrene improved the electrical, optical, and rheological properties of neat polystyrene which indicated that multiwalled carbon nanotubes were well dispersed in the polymer matrix. Results obtained from DC and AC electrical measurements revealed that the percolation threshold was around 0.8 wt% multiwalled carbon nanotubes and incorporation of 3% multiwalled carbon nanotubes into polystyrene increased polystyrene electrical conductivity up to six orders of magnitude. Besides, increasing of multiwalled carbon nanotubes loadings increased the relative dielectric permittivity, dielectric loss, and loss tangent while decreased the total impedance of polystyrene matrix. Rheological results indicated that incorporation of multiwalled carbon nanotubes into polystyrene elevated the magnitudes of storage modulus and loss modulus up to two orders of magnitude with increasing of multiwalled carbon nanotubes loadings up to 3 wt%. Finally, the addition of multiwalled carbon nanotubes to polystyrene matrix enhanced the UV/visible absorption of polystyrene and decreased the optical energy gap with a total reduction ratio of 5.8% compared to neat polystyrene with increasing multiwalled carbon nanotubes loadings up to 2 wt%.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In recent years, much researchers are attracted to the unique properties of the carbon nanotubes (CNTs)-polymer nanocomposites1–22 to create new material systems with superior size, shape, and remarkable physical performance of the nanotubes that possess high electrical conductivity, very high tensile strength, and high thermal stability,8,15,18,23 since nanotubes have found applications in various areas such as electrochemical devices, hydrogen storage, field emission devices, sensor, and probes.

One of the main challenges faced in the preparation of well-dispersed CNTs-polymer nanocomposites is that nanotubes are held together as bundles and ropes due to the existence of van der Waals attraction between them. As a result, they have very low solubility in solvents and tend to remain as entangled agglomerates. Hence, many techniques were used to improve CNTs dispersion in polymer matrix, such as ultrasonication, high shear mixing, surfactant addition, melt blending, and chemical modification through functionalization.2,3,12,24,25 Besides, such acid treatments will cause a morphological damage to CNTs and create significant physical damages.8,18,26 On the other hand, dry methods such as UV-ozone (UVO) have been an alternative treatment to resolve the issues associated with the wet oxidation. Moreover, there are studies showing that UV-modified CNTs induced a higher electrical conductivity in polymer matrices and also they reported that this method will not cause any morphological damages to CNTs.2,3,27–29

In the last few years, some studies appear to have investigated the physical properties of multiwalled carbon nanotubes–polystyrene (MWCNTs-PS) nanocomposites using different preparation methods and conditions.30–39 Despite these studies, present work demonstrates new and very interesting additions in the effect of ozone pretreatment on the electrical, rheological, and optical properties of MWCNTs-PS nanocomposites.

Present work aims to prepare functionalized MWCNTs-PS at different MWCNTs loadings. AC and DC electrical properties in addition to the rheological and optical properties of these nanocomposites are presented and discussed. The percolation threshold and optical energy gap of MWCNTs-PS nanocomposites are also presented and determined. Correlations between electrical and optical results are considered.

sec.title: Materials and film preparation
sec.p:
As-received multiwalled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) were purchased from Chengdu Organic Chemicals Co. (China) with a diameter >50 nm, length 10–20 µm, and purity >95%. The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) micrograph of the as-received MWCNTs is shown in Figure 1(a). Figure 1.
(a) Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) micrograph of the as-received multiwalled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs), (b) dispersion tests of MWCNTs in dichloromethane at different UV-ozone (UVO) exposure time, and (c) Fourier Transformed Infrared Spectrophotometer (FTIR) spectra of MWCNTs.

The functionalization of MWCNTs was performed through UV-irradiation using UV-ozone generator (Model 42-220, Jelight Co.) in ambient laboratory air at a distance of 6 mm from the lamp of power 28,000 W per cm2 and wavelength of 254 nm. The powder was stirred with a spatula at 10-min intervals to provide a uniform exposure up to 180 min. Figure 1(b) shows the dispersion of MWCNTs in dichloromethane at different UVO exposure time (0 min, 30 min, 60 min, 120 min, and 180 min). It is obvious from this figure that MWCNTs dispersion in dichloromethane solution is improved with the increase of UVO exposure time up to 180 min. However, ozone-treated MWCNTs through UVO irradiation up to 180 min were added to dichloromethane solvent and ultrasonicated for 30 min using UP 200S ultrasonicator (Hielsher Company-Ultrasonic Technology). Polystyrene (EPS 452, SABIC CO., Al Jubail, KSA) was dissolved in dichloromethane solvent and stirred at 30°C by a magnetic stirrer for 24 h. The dispersed MWCNTs in dichloromethane were then mixed with polymer solution. The mixture was again stirred for 24 h until the CNTs powder became highly dispersed in PS solution. The resultant solution was poured to glass petri dish (dia. of 10 cm). The solvent was evaporated at room temperature for 24 h. Samples with different MWCNTs-PS concentrations (0, 0.2 0.4,0.6, 0.8, 1, 1.5, 2, and 3 wt% MWCNTs) were kept inside vacuumed dissector. The film thickness (∼0.1 mm) was measured using digital micrometer (MOTOTOYO, China) with 0.001 mm resolution.

To confirm MWCNTs functionalization, a PerkinElmer 100 Fourier Transformed Infrared Spectrophotometer (FTIR) in the transmission mode was used at wavenumber range 2500–1000 cm–1. The FTIR spectra of the as received MWCNTs and ozone-treated MWCNTs for 180 min are compared in Figure 1(c). The peaks at around 1800 cm−1 and 1160 cm−1 correspond to the C--O and C = O groups on the treated CNTs surfaces. The presence of these peaks of the functionalized MWCNTs indicates that ozone-treatment through UVO irradiation leads to the production of carboxylic acid functional group on the CNTs surface.27,40–43 However, there are a lot of research27,40–43 showing that when MWCNTs are treated with ozone through the UVO irradiation up to 2 h or 4 h, MWCNTs will be functionalized and the carboxylic acid will be formed at MWCNTs surface. Moreover, Najafi et al.27 reported that treatment of MWCNTs through UV-ozone (UVO) under ambient conditions has a dramatic effect on the nature of the surface oxidation, leading to the production of quinones, esters, and hydroxyl functional groups.

sec.title: Electrical measurements
sec.p: AC and DC electrical measurements were performed using 4200-SCS Semiconductor Characterization System (KEITHLEY Co.). Prepared composite films were shaped into circular discs of area 1.2 cm2 and thickness 0.1 mm. The electrical parameters were calculated from impedance (Z) and phase angle (ϕ) values obtained from the instrument at room temperature and frequency 1 KHZ. The real (Z′) and imaginary (Z″) components of the impedance can be calculated using the following relations:44–48 (1)Z'=Zcosφ (2)Z″=Zsinφ

The relative permitivity (ε′) and dielectric loss (ε″) were calculated from the following equations46: (3)ɛ″=Z″d2πfɛ0AZ2 (4)ɛ″=z″d2πfɛ0AZ2 where d is the sample thickness, A is the cross-sectional area of the sample, ε0 is the permittivity of free space, and f is the frequency (Hz).
The AC conductivity (σac) was calculated from: (5)σac=2πfɛ0ɛ″
The loss tangent (tan(δ)) is given as: (6)tan(δ)=ɛ″ɛ″
DC electrical conductivity (σDC) was calculated at room temperature using the formula σDC =(I/V)(d/A), where I is the electrical current and V is the DC applied voltage.

sec.title: Optical properties
sec.p: The absorption spectra of prepared nanocomposites were measured in the UV/visible region at room temperature using a Shimadzu UV-VIS spectrophotometer (Model UV-3600, Japan) in the wavelength range 200–800 nm. The scan step was 0.5 nm. The optical absorbance (A) spectra of samples were collected at room temperature. After correction for reflection, the absorption coefficient α was calculated from the absorbance (A).46,47

sec.title: Mechanical properties
sec.p: Rheological measurements were carried out using DMA Q800 machine TA instruments (USA) with tension film clamping arrangement at a force of 0.5 N and strain amplitude of oscillation 15 µm at an isothermal process of 180°C and frequency of 0.2 Hz. Specimens in the form of films with dimensions 15 mm length, 4 mm width, and 0.1 mm thickness were used.

sec.title: Electrical properties
sec.p:
The room temperature DC conductivity values of prepared MWCNTs-PS nanocomposites are presented in Figure 2 as a function of MWCNTs weight fraction. It is obvious from this figure that MWCNT increases the conductivity of the nanocomposites by about six orders of magnitude, which indicates the formation of network structure between nanotubes in the polymer matrix, as a result, such a structure will facilitate the electron transport through tunneling throughout the polymer or by electron hopping along CNTs interconnects.2,5,6,46,49 Generally, electrical conductivity of CNTs-polymer composites depends on the polymer layer in the internanotube connections, which presents highly resistive section in the electrical pathway, acting as a barrier to efficient carrier transport between the nanotubes and models fluctuation-induced tunneling for the conductivity.2,9,49 When the distance between nanotubes becomes sufficiently small, the electrical response of the composites is described by percolation theory. The CNTs concentration that marks this insulator-conductor transition is referred to as the percolation threshold (Pc).2,6 Figure 2.
DC conductivity versus multiwalled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) weight fraction for MWCNTs–polystyrene (PS) nanocomposites. Scattered curve represent the experimental data, while the solid one represent the fitted data.

The percolation threshold (Pc) can be determined using the following formula:2,5,6 (6)σ=C[P-Pc]t where σ is the composite conductivity, P the weight fraction of nanotubes in the composites, C is a constant, and t is a critical exponent. A successful fitting result was obtained when the experimental data (scatter curve) was fitted with equation (6) (solid curve), see Figure 2. The obtained results reveal that the percolation threshold (Pc) of MWCNTs-PS is bout 0.8%.

Previous works showed that the electrical percolation threshold of MWCNTs-PS composites highly depends on the preparation conditions and pretreatment of MWCNTs. Yu et al.34 prepared MWCNTs-PS composites using the latex technique. Initially, they dispersed MWCNTs in aqueous solution of sodium dodecyl sulfate (SDS) driven by sonication and then mixed them with different amounts of PS latex. They found that the percolation threshold was about 1.5 wt% MWCNTs. Mathur et al.50 prepared as produced MWCNTs-PS using the casting technique. They demonstrated that the electrical conductivity appear to increase significantly only at high level of MWCNTs content (up to 10 vol%). This indicates, however, that pretreatment of MWCNTs is an important factor to improve CNTs dispersion and reduce the electrical percolation threshold. Furthermore, Cipriano et al.51 prepared MWCNTs-PS composites using the extruder method. They showed that the electrical conductivity increased up to four orders of magnitude when the weight percent of MWCNTs in PS was 1 wt%. Also, they showed that the annealing of these composites at the melting temperature reduced the electrical conductivity. However, present work shows that treatment of MWCNTs with ozone through UVO irradiation will reduce the percolation threshold up to 0.8 wt%.

Figures 3–6 show the total impedance (Z), relative permittivity (ε′), dielectric loss (ε′′), and loss tangent (tan(δ)), respectively, as a function of MWCNTs weight ratio at room temperature and frequency 1 KHz. It can be seen that the total impedance decreases up to two orders of magnitude as increasing of MWCNTs loading up to 3 wt%. Besides, the relative permittivity, dielectric loss, and loss tangent shows a jump to the higher values after the percolation threshold (0.8% MWCNTs). Also AC conductivity (Figure 7) increases up to three orders of magnitude with the increase of MWCNTs loadings up to 3 wt%. Figure 3.
Impedance (Z) versus multiwalled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) weight fraction for MWCNTs–polystyrene (PS) nanocomposites.
Figure 4.
Relative permittivity (ε′) versus multiwalled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) weight fraction for MWCNTs–polystyrene (PS) nanocomposites. Figure 5.
Dielectric loss (ε′′) versus multiwalled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) weight fraction for MWCNTs–polystyrene (PS) nanocomposites. Figure 6.
Loss tangent (tan(δ)) versus multiwalled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) weight fraction for MWCNTs–polystyrene (PS) nanocomposites.
Figure 7.
AC conductivity (σac) versus multiwalled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) weight fraction for MWCNTs–polystyrene (PS) nanocomposites.

The above results indicates that the distance between nanotubes decreases with the addition of nanotubes above the percolation threshold (0.8 wt% MWCNTs) and hence will enhance charge transfer between the nanotubes in the polymer matrix.52 Comparing present work with previous studies,31,36,38 present work shows that the functionalization of MWCNTs with ozone through UVO irradiation will improve the dispersion of nanotubes and reduce the percolation threshold up to 0.8%.

sec.title: Optical properties
sec.p:
The absorbance data (A) were collected for all samples at room temperature in the wavelength range 200 nm–800 nm and the absorption coefficient α was determined from the absorbance using the formula α = (2.303/d)A, where d is the sample thickness.47,48 Figure 8 shows the absorption spectra of MWCNTs-PS nanocomposites. It can be seen that the absorption spectra of nanocomposites represent the superposition of MWCNTs and PS absorptions. Moreover, incorporation of MWCNTs into PS matrix will enhance the UV/visible absorption of neat PS. Figure 8.
UV–VIS absorption spectra of multiwalled carbon nanotube (MWCNT)–polystyrene (PS) nanocomposites.

caption.p: (αhυ)2 versus photon energy for multiwalled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs)–polystyrene (PS) nanocomposites.

sec.p:
The dependence of the absorption coefficient α upon the photon energy hυ in semiconductor materials takes the form αhυ = k(hυ – Eopt)n, where Eopt is the optical energy gap and k is a constant. The exponent n takes the value n = 0.5 for all prepared nanocomposites with an allowed direct energy gap.46–48 The values of the optical energy gap were determined from the (αhυ)2 versus hυ plot and extrapolate the linear portions at high energy of Figures 9 and 10 to (αhυ)2 = 0.46–48 The obtained optical energy gap results are listed in Table 1. Optical energy gap results indicate that increasing of MWCNTs loading up to 2 wt% will decrease the optical energy gap from 4.48 eV up to 4.22 eV, with a total reduction ratio of 5.8% compared to neat PS. Such a decrease could be attributed to the formation of localized states in the forbidden gap.46,47,53 Figure 10.
(αhυ)2 versus photon energy for polystyrene (PS) and 2% multiwalled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs)–polystyrene (PS) nanocomposite.
Table 1.
The values of optical energy gap (Eopt) of MWCNTs–PS nanocomposites
MWCNTs wt% Optical energy gap (Eopt) (eV)
0 4.48
0.2 4.47
0.4 4.45
0.6 4.43
0.8 4.41
1.0 4.25
2.0 4.22
MWCNTs: multiwalled carbon nanotubes; PS: polystyrene.

sec.title: Mechanical properties
sec.p:
The rheology of the MWCNTs-PS nanocomposites was measured through dynamic rheological measurements at low frequency (0.2 Hz) and temperature 180°C. The storage modulus G′ and the loss modulus G′′ as functions of MWCNTs weight fraction are presented in Figures 11 and 12. It is clear that both G′ and G′′ increases up to two order of magnitudes with increasing MWCNTs weight ratio up to 3 wt%. Obtained results indicate that the percolated MWCNTs form network with strong interactions between polymer and MWCNTs.14,31,34,35,39 Figure 11.
Storage modulus (G′) versus multiwalled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) weight fraction for MWCNTs–polystyrene (PS) nanocomposites.
Figure 12.
Loss modulus (G′′) versus multiwalled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) weight fraction for MWCNTs–polystyrene (PS) nanocomposites.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Ozone-treated MWCNTs-PS nanocomposites were prepared at different MWCNTs loadings to investigate the effect of MWCNTs loadings in the electrical, rheological, and optical properties of PS matrix. All obtained results indicate that incorporation of functionalized MWCNTs into PS will improve electrical, rheological, and optical properties of PS matrix and the improvement over PS properties suggest that MWCNTs are well dispersed in the PS matrix. The electrical results either at DC or AC applied electric field reveal that the percolation threshold is around 0.8% MWCNTs and incorporation of 3% MWCNTs into PS will elevate the DC electrical conductivity of PS up to six orders of magnitude. Also, addition of MWCNTs to PS matrix will enhance relative permitivity, dielectric loss, and AC conductivity while will decrease the total impedance of PS. Rheological results indicate that incorporation of MWCNTs in PS will elevate the magnitudes of storage modulus and loss modulus up to two order of magnitudes with increasing of MWCNTs loadings up to 3 wt%. Finally, addition of MWCNTs to PS matrix will enhance the UV/visible absorption of PS and decrease the optical energy gap with a total reduction ratio of 5.8% compared to neat PS with increasing MWCNTs loadings up to 2 wt%.

ack.title: Acknowledgments
ack.p: The authors acknowledge the King Abdelaziz City for Science and Technology (KACST), Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, for funding and providing all the facilities required to perform this research, which represents a part of the strategic project with ID NO: 10-NAN724-06.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
